Let  

\[
k=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon _0},\qquad  
L=4z .
\]

The two grounded plates lie at \(x=0\) and \(x=L\).
Real charges are

\[
+\,Q\;\hbox{at}\;x=z ,\qquad   
-\,Q\;\hbox{at}\;x=3z .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a)   Energy required to take the charges to infinity

When the two charges are moved from the inter‑plate region to spatial
infinity the work performed is the **electrostatic energy**
stored in the field that exists between the plates before removal,
because the plates remain grounded during the process.

Using the method of images the field between the plates is identical
with that obtained by replacing each plate by an infinite series of
image charges.  
The resulting interaction energy reduces to the mutual attraction
of the two real charges – all other contributions cancel owing to the
grounding of the plates. Hence

\[
U_{\text{int}}
    =-\frac{k\,Q^{2}}{\lvert 3z-z\rvert}
     =-\frac{k\,Q^{2}}{2z}.
\]

Since the self–energies of the point charges are cancelled by the
work done on the grounded plates, the total energy that must be supplied
is therefore

\[
\boxed{W_{\rm req}=+\displaystyle\frac{k\,Q^{2}}{2z}}\tag{1}
\]
(the positive sign indicating that work must be done against the attractive
force).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b)   Forces on the charges

Each charge feels the field generated by the other charge **and** by
the induced charges on the plates.  
With the image‑charge picture the field acting on a real charge is
identical to that produced by the other real charge alone;
all image contributions cancel at the position of the real charge.
Consequently

\[
F_{(+)}=
      k\,\frac{Q^{2}}{(2z)^{2}}
      =\frac{k\,Q^{2}}{4z^{2}},\quad
F_{(-)}=-F_{(+)}
\]

directed respectively **toward** the centre of the capacitor.
In words,

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{On }+Q:\;& F=\frac{kQ^{2}}{4z^{2}}\;\hat{x}\;( {\rm inward}),\\[2pt]
&\text{On }-Q:\;& F=-\frac{kQ^{2}}{4z^{2}}\;\hat{x}\;( {\rm inward}) .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (c)   Forces on the plates

By Newton’s third law the forces exerted on the plates are equal and
opposite to the forces on the charges.  
Both plates experience a pull toward the centre of the capacitor:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Left plate:}& F_L &= -\,\frac{kQ^{2}}{4z^{2}}\;\hat{x}\\[2pt]
&\text{Right plate:}& F_R &= +\,\frac{kQ^{2}}{4z^{2}}\;\hat{x}
\end{aligned}}
\tag{3}
\]

(The arrows indicate that the left plate is pulled to the right and
vice versa.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (d)   Total induced charge on each plate

The potential on the plane halfway between the two real charges
(\(x=2z\)) is

\[
V(2z)=k\!\left[\frac{Q}{z}-\frac{Q}{z}\right]=0 ,
\]

so that plane behaves as a “virtual” grounded sheet.  
From the uniqueness theorem the induced charge on each physical plate
must therefore be **equal in magnitude and opposite in sign**, namely

\[
\boxed{Q_{\text{ind,left}}=-Q,\qquad
       Q_{\text{ind,right}}=+Q }\tag{4}
\]

(these charges sit entirely on the inner surfaces of the plates).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (e)   Induced charge after removing the \(-Q\) charge

After taking the \(-Q\) charge to infinity only the \(+Q\) charge
remains.  
Its image with respect to the left plate is \(-Q\) at \(x=-z\);  
its image with respect to the right plate is \(-Q\) at \(x=7z\),
which in turn produces higher‑order images, forming an infinite
alternating string.  
Summation of this geometric series shows that the net induced charge
on the **inner** surface of the left plate is

\[
\boxed{Q_{\text{ind,left,int}}=-\,Q},
\]

while the inner surface of the right plate receives no induced charge
(since the field lines end on the left plate):

\[
\boxed{Q_{\text{ind,right,int}}=0 } .
\]

The outer surfaces retain the compensating charges necessary to keep
each plate electrically neutral with respect to the ground.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

These results follow directly from the method of images and the fact
that the plates are held at zero potential throughout the process.

### (a)  Maxwell–equations in free space  

In free space (\(\rho _{f}=0,\;\mathbf J_{f}=0\))

\[
\nabla\!\cdot\!\mathbf B=0 ,\qquad

\]

Both Maxwell equations are satisfied with \(\mathbf J_f=0\);

Field lines follow

xy=C .

They are the family of rectangular hyperbolæ

symmetrical with respect to the axes.
Each branch lies entirely in one of the four quadrants.

```

   | \_____|_____/
   |______|

```

quadrants.)

To obtain such a field one needs a **continuous volume current**
whose curl vanishes everywhere.  
An idealised approximation consists of a very dense array of
infinitesimally short current elements running along the \(z\)–axis
and positioned so that their individual Biot–Savart contributions add
up to the linear profile (1).  In practice the field can be realised
only locally; far away the necessary currents become impractically

### (c)  Magnetic flux per unit length in the \(\hat z\)–direction  

Take a cut at fixed \(z=z_0\).  
Between the origin and the chosen field line the relevant surface is
the portion of the \(xy\)–plane bounded by the axes and the curve

\[

\]

\[

### (a)   Static cylindrical column  

Consider an infinitely long cylinder of radius \(a\) filled with electrons having a **proper** (rest‑frame) volumetric charge density  
\[
\rho_{0}\;(<0).
\]
Choose a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius \(r<a\) and length \(L\).  
Gauss’ law (\(\oint {\bf E}\!\cdot{\rm d}{\bf A}=Q_{\rm enc}/\varepsilon _0\)) gives

\[
E_\perp\, (2\pi rL)=\frac{\rho_{0}\,\pi r^{2}L}{\varepsilon _0}
      \;\Longrightarrow\;
E_\perp=\frac{\rho_{0}}{2\varepsilon _0}\,r .
\]

Because \(\rho_{0}<0\), the electric field points **towards** the axis.  
An electron (\(q=-e\)) therefore feels a radial force

\[
\boxed{
{\bf F}_{\rm stat}(r)=q\,{\bf E}_\perp=
-\frac{e|\rho_{0}|}{2\varepsilon _0}\,r\,\hat{\mathbf r}}
\qquad (r<a),
\]

i.e. a repulsive force directed outward from the centre.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Laboratory observation of a moving beam  

In the laboratory the beam carries a measured charge density \(\rho\) and travels with speed \(v\) along the \(z\)–axis.  
Its current density is \(J=\rho\,v\).  
Inside the beam (\(r<a\))

\[
\nabla\times{\bf B}=\mu _0 J ,\qquad   
\nabla\!\cdot{\bf E}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon _0}.
\]

Solving these symmetric equations gives

\[
E_\perp(r)=\frac{\rho }{2\varepsilon _0}\,r ,
\qquad    
B_\phi(r)=\frac{\mu _0 J}{2}\,r
          =\frac{\mu _0\rho v}{2}\,r .
\]

(The magnetic field circles the beam.)

The Lorentz force on a beam electron is

\[
{\bf F}_{\rm lab}=q\bigl({\bf E}+{\bf v}\times{\bf B}\bigr).
\]

With \(q=-e\),

\[
{\bf v}\times{\bf B}
    =v\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times(B_\phi\,\hat{\boldsymbol\varphi})
    =-\,\frac{\mu _0\rho v^{2}}{2}\,r\,\hat{\mathbf r},
\]

so that

\[
{\bf F}_{\rm lab}
     =-e\left[\frac{\rho }{2\varepsilon _0}-\frac{\mu _0\rho v^{2}}{2}\right]r\,\hat{\mathbf r}
     =-e\,\frac{\rho }{2\varepsilon _0}\Bigl(1-\beta ^2\gamma ^{-2}\Bigr)\,r\,\hat{\mathbf r},
\]
where \(\beta=v/c\) and \(\gamma =(1-\beta ^2)^{-1/2}\).

Noting that \(\mu _0\varepsilon _0=c^{-2}\) and simplifying,

\[
\boxed{{\bf F}_{\rm lab}(r)=
        -\,\frac{e\,\rho }{2\varepsilon _0\,\gamma ^2}\,r\,\hat{\mathbf r}},
        \qquad (r<a).
\]

The force is still outward (repulsive); however it is diminished by a factor \(\gamma ^2\) relative to the static case.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Observation comoving with the beam  

In the beam’s own rest frame the magnetic field vanishes.  
Only the electric field survives, producing

\[
{\bf F}'(r)=q\,{\bf E}'
           =-\,\frac{e\,\rho _0}{2\varepsilon _0}\,r\,\hat{\mathbf r},
\]
with \(\rho _0=\rho/\gamma\) being the proper charge density.

Comparing with the laboratory result,

\[
\frac{|{\bf F}'|}{|{\bf F}_{\rm lab}|}
       =\gamma ^2 .
\]

Thus the comoving observer measures a repulsive force larger by a factor \(\gamma ^2\); the reduction seen in the laboratory comes entirely from the magnetic field generated by the beam’s motion.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (d)   Required magnetic‑field gradient to prevent transverse spread  

Take

\[
n=2\times10^{10}\;{\rm cm^{-3}}\quad\Rightarrow\quad
n=2\times10^{16}\;{\rm m^{-3}},\\[2mm]
v=0.99c,\qquad \gamma\simeq7.09 .
\]

Lab charge density  
\[
\rho=n\,e=2\times10^{16}\,(1.602\times10^{-19})\approx3.20\times10^{-3}\;{\rm C\,m^{-3}} .
\]

Space‑charge force per unit mass (from part (b)):
\[
F_{\rm sc}= \frac{e\,\rho }{2\varepsilon _0\,\gamma ^2}\,r .
\]

To balance this, an external transverse magnetic field \(B_{\perp}(x)\) with spatial derivative \(G=dB_{\perp}/dx\) supplies a Lorentz force

\[
F_B = e\,v\, G\, r .
\]

Setting \(F_B=F_{\rm sc}\) and cancelling \(r\),

\[
G=\frac{\rho}{2\varepsilon _0\,\gamma ^2\,v}
   =\frac{3.20\times10^{-3}}
         {2(8.854\times10^{-12})(7.09)^2(0.99\,c)} .
\]

Numerically,

\[
G \approx 1.2\times10^{-2}\;{\rm T\,m^{-1}} .
\]

\[
\boxed{ \displaystyle \frac{dB_{\perp}}{dx}\;\approx\;1\times10^{-2}\ {\rm tesla\ per\ metre}. }
\]

A transverse magnetic-field gradient of roughly ten milliteslas per metre would suffice to halt the natural transverse expansion caused by the beam’s space‑charge forces under the stated conditions.

Let \(S'\) be the inertial frame in which the charged particle is instantaneously at rest  
(\(v_{\,\text{particle}}=0\)).  
In this frame the electrostatic field of a point charge \(q\) is purely Coulombic  

\[
\boxed{
\mathbf {E}'(\mathbf r')
   =\frac{q\,\hat {\mathbf r'}}{{|\mathbf r'}|^{\,3}},\qquad   
     \mathbf B'=\mathbf 0 ,
}
\tag{1}
\]
with \(\hat{\mathbf r'}=\mathbf r'/|\mathbf r'|\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1. Geometry – relating the two frames

The laboratory frame \(S\) moves relative to \(S'\) with velocity  
\(+\!v\,\hat{\bf x}\;(v>0)\).  
A space–time event measured in \(S\) at time \(t\) and spatial location
\((x,y,z)\) corresponds in \(S'\) to

\[
\begin{aligned}
X &=\gamma\,(x-vt),\\
Y &= y,\qquad    
Z = z .
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

(The factor \(\gamma=(1-\beta ^2)^{-1/2}\) comes from length‑contraction
along the direction of motion.)  
Consequently

\[
|\mathbf r'|^2=X^2+Y^2+Z^2=
      \gamma^2(x-vt)^2+y^2+z^2 .
\tag{3}
\]

Define

\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle
\chi\equiv\Bigl[\gamma^2(x-vt)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
\tag{4}
\]
so that \(|\mathbf r'|^3=\chi\).

Using Eq.(2) in Eq.(1),

\[
\begin{aligned}
E'_x&=\frac{q\,X}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,\gamma(x-vt)}{\chi},\\[2mm]
E'_y&=\frac{q\,Y}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,y}{\chi},\\[2mm]
E'_z&=\frac{q\,Z}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,z}{\chi}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2. Lorentz transformation of the fields

For a pure boost along the \(x\)-direction (\({\boldsymbol\beta}=\beta\,\hat{\bf x}\))
the standard relations between the fields in \(S\) and those in \(S'\) read

\[
\begin{cases}
E_{\parallel}=E'_{\parallel}, \\[1ex]
E_{\perp}=\gamma\!\bigl(E'_{\perp}+{\boldsymbol\beta}\times c\,\mathbf B'\bigr),
          &(\text{here }\mathbf B'=0),\\[1ex]
\mathbf B=\gamma\!\bigl(\mathbf B'-\dfrac{{\boldsymbol\beta}\times\mathbf E'}
                               {c}\bigr)
        =-\gamma\,{\boldsymbol\beta}\times\mathbf E'.
\end{cases}
\tag{6}
\]

Because \(\mathbf B'=0\) all magnetic contributions come solely from the last term.

*Electric field*

Parallel to the boost (\(x\))-component stays unchanged:

\[
E_x=E'_x=\frac{q\,\gamma(x-vt)}{\chi}.
\]

Perpendicular components acquire a factor \(\gamma\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_y&=\gamma\,E'_y
    =\gamma\,\frac{q\,y}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,\gamma y}{\chi},\\[1ex]
E_z&=\gamma\,E'_z
    =\gamma\,\frac{q\,z}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,\gamma z}{\chi}.
\end{aligned}
\]

These agree exactly with the required expressions.

*Magnetic field*

With \({\boldsymbol\beta}=\beta\,\hat{\bf x}\) one finds

\[
{\boldsymbol\beta}\times\mathbf E'
   =\beta\hat{\bf x}\times
     \bigl(E'_x\hat{\bf x}+E'_y\hat{\bf y}+E'_z\hat{\bf z}\bigr)
   =\beta\bigl(E'_y\hat{\bf z}-E'_z\hat{\bf y}\bigr).
\]

Therefore

\[
\begin{aligned}
B_y&=-\gamma\,\beta\,E'_z
    =-\gamma\,\beta\,\frac{q\,z}{\chi}
    =-\frac{q\,\beta\gamma z}{\chi},\\[1ex]
B_z&=\phantom{-}\gamma\,\beta\,E'_y
    =\gamma\,\beta\,\frac{q\,y}{\chi}
    =\frac{q\,\beta\gamma y}{\chi},\\[1ex]
B_x&=0 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Again these coincide precisely with the stated results.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

## Result

Collecting everything,

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
E_x &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,(x-vt), &
B_x &= 0,\\[1ex]
E_y &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,y, &
B_y &= -\,\frac{q}{\chi}\,\beta\,\gamma\,z,\\[1ex]
E_z &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,z, &
B_z &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\beta\,\gamma\,y,
\end{aligned}}\qquad
\chi=[\gamma^2(x-vt)^2+y^2+z^2]^{3/2}.
\]

This completes the demonstration that a uniformly moving point charge produces the specified electric and magnetic fields.

&\phi(a,\theta)=0,     &&\tfrac{\pi }{2}<\theta<\tfrac{3\pi }{2}.
\end{aligned}}
\tag{1}
\]

No net charge exists, therefore the potential must tend to zero when
\(r\rightarrow\infty\).

---

Regularity at the centre requires a power‑series expansion containing only
positive integer powers of \(r\),

\[
\phi_{\rm in}(r,\theta)=A_{0}+\sum _{n=1}^{\infty }
\! \bigl(B_{n}r^{\,n}\cos n\theta+C_{n}r^{\,n}\sin n\theta\bigr),
\qquad r<a .
\tag{2}
\]

From the symmetry of the boundary data (the potential is an even function of
\(\theta\)) all \(C_{n}=0\).   
Matching Eq.(1) gives the Fourier coefficients

\[
A_{0}=\frac{1}{2\pi }\int_{-\pi }^{\pi }f(\theta )\,d\theta
      =\frac{V_{0}}{2},
\quad 
B_{n}=\frac{1}{\pi }\int_{-\pi }^{\pi }f(\theta )
          \cos n\theta \,d\theta ,
\qquad f(\theta )\equiv\phi(a,\theta ).
\]

With \(f(\theta )=V_{0}\) for \(|\theta|<\pi /2\) and \(0\) elsewhere,

\[
B_{n}=\frac{V_{0}}{\pi }\!
        \int_{-\pi /2}^{\;\pi /2}\!\cos n\theta \,d\theta
    =\frac{2V_{0}}{\pi n}\sin\!\frac{n\pi }{2}.
\]

Only odd harmonics survive, and \(\displaystyle
\sin\!\frac{(2k+1)\pi }{2}=(-1)^{k}\). Hence

\[
\boxed{
\phi_{\rm in}(r,\theta)=\frac{V_{0}}{2}
+\frac{2V_{0}}{\pi }\;
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}}{2k+1}
\Bigl(\frac{r}{a}\Bigr)^{2k+1}\cos [(2k+1)\theta],
\qquad r<a.}
\tag{3}
\]

In the outer region the potential must remain finite at infinity, thus

\[

\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{D_{n}}{r^{\,n}}\cos n\theta ,
\qquad r>a .
\tag{4}
\]

\[

\]

\frac{2V_{0}}{\pi }\;
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k}}{2k+1}
\Bigl(\frac{a}{r}\Bigr)^{2k+1}\cos [(2k+1)\theta],

### (a)   General form  

In SI units the differential power emitted into a solid‑angle element \(d\Omega\) by a non–relativistic accelerated charge \(q=e\) is obtained from the far‑field electric field  
\[
E_{\rm rad}(t,r,\hat{\bf n})
      =\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon _0c^2}
        \;\frac{\hat{\bf n}\times[\,
          (\hat{\bf n}-\boldsymbol{\beta})\times\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}
         ]}
              {(1-\hat{\bf n}\!\cdot\! \boldsymbol{\beta})^{3}},
     \qquad 
     \boldsymbol{\beta}\equiv\frac{{\bf v}}{c},
\]
where \(\hat{\bf n}\) is the unit vector pointing from the source to the observer.  
The corresponding Poynting flux is

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\frac{dP}{d\Omega}
    =r^{2}\langle S\rangle
    =\frac{q^{2}}{16\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c }
       \Bigg|
           \frac{\hat{\bf n}\times[(\hat{\bf n}-\boldsymbol{\beta})\times\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}]}
                { (1-\hat{\bf n}\!\cdot\!\boldsymbol{\beta})^{3}}
       \Bigg|^{2}
}
\tag{1}
\]

Because the problem states “non‑relativistic”, \(|\boldsymbol{\beta}|=\beta\ll1\);
hence all factors containing \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) in Eq.(1) reduce to unity:
\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\biggl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\biggr\rangle
=
\frac{q^{2}}{16\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c }\;
 |\hat{\bf n}\times({\bf a}/c)|^{2}
 =
\frac{q^{2}}{16\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c }\,a^{2}\sin ^{2}\gamma ,
}
\tag{2}
\]
with \({\bf a}=\dot {\bf v}\) the acceleration and \(\gamma\) the angle between
the acceleration vector and the line of sight.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Linear harmonic motion \(z(t)=a\cos\omega _0t\)

Here   
\[
\begin{aligned}
{\bf v}&=(-a\omega _0)\sin\omega _0t\,\hat{\bf z},\\
{\bf a}&=(-a\omega _0^{2})\cos\omega _0t\,\hat{\bf z}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Let \((\theta ,\phi )\) denote the usual spherical angles of \(\hat{\bf n}\).
Since \({\bf a}\parallel\hat{\bf z}\),

\[
\sin\gamma =\sqrt{1-(\hat{\bf n}\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf z})^{2}}
            =\sin\theta .
\]

Using Eq.(2):

\[
\frac{dP}{d\Omega}(t)
   =\frac{e^{2}}{16\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c}\,
     a^{2}\omega _0^{4}\cos ^{2}\!(\omega _0t)\,
     \sin ^{2}\theta .
\]

Averaging over one mechanical period \(T=2\pi/\omega _0\),
\(\langle\cos ^{2}\rangle =1/2\):

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\biggl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\biggr\rangle
   =\frac{e^{2}a^{2}\omega _0^{4}}{32\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c}\;
     \sin ^{2}\theta .
}
\tag{3}
\]

This is the familiar **dipole pattern**, vanishing along the \(+\!z,-\!z\) axes
and maximal in the transverse plane.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Uniform circular motion in the \(x y\)-plane

Take the centre of the circle as the origin and let the particle move with
constant speed \(v=R\omega _0\):
\[
{\bf r}(t)=R(\cos\omega _0t,\;\sin\omega _0t,\;0),\qquad
{\bf a}(t)=-R\omega _0^{2}(\cos\omega _0t,\;\sin\omega _0t,\;0).
\]

Again use Eq.(2).  
At fixed observation direction \(\hat{\bf n}=(\sin\theta\cos\varphi',
                                   \sin\theta\sin\varphi',
                                   \cos\theta)\) the cosine of the angle
between \({\bf a}\) and \(\hat{\bf n}\) reads

\[
\cos\gamma(t)=
\frac{{\bf a}\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf n}}{|{\bf a}|}
=-\sin\theta\cos(\omega _0t-\varphi').
\]

Hence
\[
\sin ^{2}\gamma(t)=1-\sin ^{2}\theta\cos ^{2}(\omega _0t-\varphi')
                 =1-\frac12\sin ^{2}\theta+
                   \frac12\sin ^{2}\theta\cos 2(\omega _0t-\varphi') .
\]

Time–average over one revolution eliminates the last term:
\[
\overline{\sin ^{2}\gamma}
   =1-\frac12\sin ^{2}\theta
   =\frac12\,(1+\cos ^{2}\theta ).
\]

Therefore

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
\biggl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\biggr\rangle
   =\frac{e^{2}R^{2}\omega _0^{4}}{32\pi ^{2}\epsilon _0c}\;
     \bigl(1+\cos ^{2}\theta\bigr).
}
\tag{4}
\]

It is independent of the azimuthal angle \(\varphi'\); the radiation is
axisymmetric about the \(z\)-axis.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (d)   Sketches of the angular distributions

| Motion | Pattern |
|--------|---------|
| **Linear harmonic** (Eq.\;(3)) | Dipolar “donut” : intensity \(\propto\sin ^{2}\theta\). Maximal in the plane normal to the vibration axis, nodes along the axis. |
| **Circular** (Eq.\;(4)) | Axisymmetric lobe: intensity varies as \((1+\cos ^{2}\theta)/2\). Highest along the rotation axis (\(\theta=0,\pi\)), lowest in the orbital plane (\(\theta=\pi/2\)). |

Both patterns lie entirely outside the lightcone of the instantaneous velocity
(the latter being purely transverse for the linear case, and confined to the
orbital plane for the circular case).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (e)   What happens in the relativistic regime?

When \(\beta=v/c\sim1\) the exact Liénard–Wiechert fields must be used.
Key consequences are

1. **Beaming:**  
   The factor \([1-\hat{\bf n}\!\cdot\!\boldsymbol{\beta}]^{-3}\) in Eq.(1)
   concentrates most of the power inside a narrow cone whose half‑opening
   angle scales as \(\Delta\theta\simeq 1/\gamma\) (\(\gamma=[1-\beta ^{2}]^{-1/2}\)).
   Observers situated even slightly ahead of the instantaneous velocity see
   almost all the radiation.

2. **Intensity amplification:**  
   The total radiated power grows roughly as \(\gamma^{6}\) for synchrotron–
   type motions, while the peak specific intensity rises proportionally to
   \(\gamma^{4}\).

3. **Spectral shift:**  
   Frequencies are Doppler‑boosted by a factor \(\approx\gamma(1+\beta\cos\psi)\),
   producing high‑frequency harmonics (“synchrotron spectrum”).

Consequently, instead of the smooth dipole or modestly modulated patterns above,
one obtains extremely sharp, narrowly collimated beams directed nearly parallel
to the instantaneous velocity—an effect responsible for pulsar radio pulses
and astrophysical jets.

The electric field is taken to act along one spatial axis (say \(x\)), so all vectors point in this direction.

### (a) Final momentum  

In special–relativity the equation of motion for a free charge in an external electromagnetic field reads  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}t}( \gamma m {\bf v})=
q\bigl({\bf E}+{\bf v}\times{\bf B}\bigr).
\]

With \({\bf B}=0\) and \(q=e\),

\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle 
\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}t}\!\Bigl(\gamma m v_x\Bigr)
   = eE .
}
\]

Integrating from \(t=0\) to \(t=T\) and using the fact that the particle was at rest initially,

\[
\boxed{\;
p(T)\equiv \gamma m v_x = eET .
}
\tag{1}
\]

Hence the magnitude of the momentum after the acceleration period is simply the product of the applied force and the elapsed time – exactly as in classical mechanics.

---

### (b) Final velocity  

From Eq.(1) we have

\[
p = \gamma m v ,
\qquad
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}},\quad
\beta=\frac{v}{c}.
\]

Introduce the convenient variable  

\[
u\equiv\frac{p}{mc}=\frac{eET}{mc},
\]
which is dimensionless.  
Solving for \(\beta\):

\[
u=\frac{\beta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}
}\Longrightarrow
\beta^{2}=\frac{u^{2}}{1+u^{2}},
\qquad
\beta=\frac{u}{\sqrt{1+u^{2}}}.
\]

Therefore

\[
\boxed{
v(T)=c\,\frac{u}{\sqrt{1+u^{2}}}
      =\frac{eET}{m}\,
        \frac{1}{\sqrt{\,1+
          \left(\dfrac{eET}{mc}\right)^{2}}}\;}
\tag{2}
\]

or, equivalently,

\[
v(T)=\frac{pc^{2}}{\sqrt{p^{2}c^{2}+m^{2}c^{4}}},
\qquad p=eET .
\]

This expression reduces to the familiar non‑relativistic limit \(v\simeq eET/m\) when \(eET\ll mc\).

---

### (c) Dilated lifetime  

If the particle’s proper (rest‑frame) mean life is \(\tau\),
the laboratory observer measures a longer lifetime owing to time dilation:

\[
T_{\text{lab}}=\gamma\,\tau .
\]

Using the value of \(\gamma\) corresponding to the velocity obtained in (b),

\[
\gamma=\sqrt{1+u^{2}}
       =\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{eET}{mc}\right)^{2}} .
\]

Consequently

\[
\boxed{\;
T_{\text{lab}}
     =\tau\,\sqrt{1+\left(
         \frac{eET}{mc}\right)^{2}}
    }
\tag{3}
\]

is the lifetime seen by the stationary observer once the particle has finished accelerating and travels uniformly with the velocity given in (2).

Let  

\[
E=\gamma\,m_ec^{2}\qquad(\gamma\equiv{\rm Lorentz\;factor}), 
\]
\(q=-e\;(e>0)\) be the elementary charge, \(R\) the orbital radius,
and \(c\simeq 2.99792\times10^{8}{\rm m\,s^{-1}}\).
All quantities are taken in SI units unless otherwise stated.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a) Magnetic‑field strength required for a circular orbit

For a relativistic particle in a homogeneous magnetic field the balance
between the Lorentz force and the centrifugal “force’’ reads

\[
q\,v\,B=\frac{\gamma m_ev^{2}}{R},
\]

hence

\[
B=\frac{\gamma m_{e}v}{qR}.
\tag{1}
\]

Using  
\(v=c\sqrt{1-\dfrac{1}{\gamma ^2}}\) and \(\displaystyle \gamma=
\dfrac{E}{m_ec^{2}}\),

\[
B=\frac{E\,c}{qR}\;
      \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{m_ec^{2}}{E}\right)^{2}}
   =\frac{\sqrt{E^{2}-\bigl(m_ec^{2}\bigr)^{2}}}{qRc } .
\tag{2}
\]

---

#### Numerical evaluation

Parameters  

\[
\begin{aligned}
&R=30\ {\rm m},\\
&E=2.5\times10^{9}\ {\rm eV}=4.00544\times10^{-10}\ {\rm J},\\
&m_e=9.10938\times10^{-31}\ {\rm kg},\\
&e=1.60218\times10^{-19}\ {\rm C}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Because \(E\gg m_ec^{2}\,(=8.187\times10^{-14}\ {\rm J})\),
the square–root factor differs from unity only by \(<10^{-8}\);
we therefore take it as 1 for practical purposes.

From Eq.(2)

\[
B\simeq\frac{E\,c}{e\,R\,c}
     =\frac{E}{eR}
     =\frac{4.00544\times10^{-10}}{{1.60218\times10^{-19}\cdot30}}
     =2.779\times10^{-1}\ {\rm T}.
\]

Converting tesla to gauss (\(1\,{\rm T}=10^{4}\,{\rm G}\))

\[
\boxed{B\;\approx\;2.78\times10^{3}\ {\rm G}} .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b) Fractional energy loss per revolution

Synchrotron radiation power for a relativistic charge on a circular path
(Liénard’s formula) is

\[
P=\frac{q^{2}c}{6\pi\varepsilon _0}\,\frac{\beta ^{4}\gamma ^{4}}{R^{2}},
\quad\text{with }\beta=v/c\approx1 .
\]

With \(\beta\simeq1\) the power reduces to

\[
P\simeq\frac{q^{2}c}{6\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
        \frac{\gamma ^{4}}{R^{2}} .
\tag{3}
\]

One revolution takes a time 

\[
T=\frac{2\pi R}{v}\simeq\frac{2\pi R}{c}.
\]

Hence the energy lost per turn,

\[
\Delta E=P\,T
       =\frac{q^{2}c}{6\pi\varepsilon _0}\,
         \frac{\gamma ^{4}}{R^{2}}\;
          \frac{2\pi R}{c}
       =\frac{q^{2}\gamma ^{4}}{3\varepsilon _0 R}.
\tag{4}
\]

Dividing by the total energy \(E=\gamma m_ec^{2}\),

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\Delta E}{E}
    =\frac{q^{2}\gamma ^{3}}
           {3\varepsilon _0\,m_e\,c^{2}\,R}
    }
\tag{5}
\]

which depends only on fundamental constants, the beam energy through
\(\gamma\), and the bend radius \(R\).

---

#### Numerical evaluation

Insert the data used before:

\[
\begin{aligned}
&q=e=1.60218\times10^{-19}\ {\rm C},\\
&\varepsilon _0=8.85419\times10^{-12}\ {\rm F\,m^{-1}},\\
&m_e=9.10938\times10^{-31}\ {\rm kg},\\
&R=30\ {\rm m},\\
&\gamma=\frac{E}{m_ec^{2}}
        =\frac{4.00544\times10^{-10}}
               {8.18710\times10^{-14}}
        \approx 4.90\times10^{3}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Computing Eq.(5):

\[
\frac{\Delta E}{E}
   =\frac{(1.60218\times10^{-19})^{2}(4.90\times10^{3})^{3}}
          {3(8.85419\times10^{-12})(9.10938\times10^{-31})
            (2.99792\times10^{8})^{2}(30)}
   \approx 4.6\times10^{-5}.
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{\Delta E}{E}\;\approx\;4.6\times10^{-5}\;\;({\rm i.e.\;about\;0.0046\%}).}
\]

This confirms that the assumed condition \(\Delta E\ll E\) is well satisfied.

The sphere is made of a linear, isotropic, homogeneous dielectric whose relative permittivity  
\( \displaystyle \epsilon=\frac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon _0}\).
It sits in free space (\(\varepsilon _0\)).  
Far away the imposed field is  

\[
\mathbf {E}_0=E_0\,\hat {\bf z},\qquad 
V_{\infty }=-E_0\,z=-E_0\,r\cos\theta .
\]

Because the geometry is axially symmetric about \(z\), the electrostatic potential depends on
the polar angle \(\theta\) only through \(\cos\theta\); therefore it contains only the
dipolar (\(l=1\)) part of the Legendre expansion.

---

### 1. Potentials

Let  

\[
\Phi_{\text{int}}(r,\theta)=A\,r\cos\theta ,\qquad   (r<R)
\]
\[
\Phi_{\text{ext}}(r,\theta)=-E_0\,r\cos\theta+\frac{B\cos\theta}{r^{2}},\qquad (r>R)
\]

where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants to be found from the boundary conditions at \(r=R\):

1. **Continuity of the scalar potential**
   \[
   \Phi_{\text{int}}(R,\theta)=\Phi_{\text{ext}}(R,\theta)\;\Longrightarrow\;
   AR=-E_0R+\frac{B}{R^{2}}\quad\Rightarrow\quad
   B=(AR+E_0R^{3}).                                    \tag{BC‑1}
   \]

2. **Continuity of the radial component of the electric displacement**
   \[
   \varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,\left.\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{int}}}{\partial r}\right|_{R^{-}}
     =\varepsilon_0\,\left.\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{ext}}}{\partial r}\right|_{R^{+}},
   \]
   i.e.
   \[
   \varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,A\cos\theta=
      \varepsilon_0\!\Big[-E_0\cos\theta-\frac{2B\cos\theta}{R^{3}}\Big].
   \]
   Cancelling common factors,
   \[
   \varepsilon A=-E_0-\frac{2B}{R^{3}}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
   B=-\frac{R^{3}}{2}\big(E_0+\varepsilon A\big).\tag{BC‑2}
   \]

Solving (BC‑1)–(BC‑2) yields

\[
A=\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2},
\qquad
B=E_0\,R^{3}\,\frac{\varepsilon-1}{\varepsilon+2}.
\]

Therefore

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\Phi_{\text{int}}(r,\theta)&=
    \frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\,r\cos\theta ,
\\[4pt]
\Phi_{\text{ext}}(r,\theta)&=
    -E_0\,r\cos\theta+
    \frac{E_0\,R^{3}(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}
        \frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}}
\]

---

### 2. Electric Fields

Since \(\mathbf{E}=-\boldsymbol\nabla\Phi\),

#### Inside (\(r<R\))

Only the first term contributes:
\[
\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm int}}
   =-\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{int}}}{\partial r}\,\hat{\mathbf r}
    -\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{int}}}{\partial\theta}\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}
   =-\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\cos\theta\,\hat{\mathbf r}
     +\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}
   =\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\,\hat{\mathbf z}.
\]

Thus the interior field is spatially uniform,

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm int}}=\frac{3}{\varepsilon+2}\,E_0\,\hat{\mathbf z}} .
\]

#### Outside (\(r>R\))

Using the full exterior potential,

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_r &= -\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{ext}}}{\partial r}
     =E_0\cos\theta-
       \frac{2E_0R^{3}(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}\frac{\cos\theta}{r^{3}}, \\[4pt]
E_\theta &=-\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial\Phi_{\text{ext}}}{\partial\theta}
          =-E_0\sin\theta+
            \frac{E_0R^{3}(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}\frac{\sin\theta}{r^{3}} .
\end{aligned}
\]

In Cartesian form this may also be written compactly as

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm ext}}(\mathbf r)=
E_0\,\hat{\mathbf z}
+\frac{E_0R^{3}(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}\,
\frac{3(\hat{\mathbf r}\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf z})\hat{\mathbf r}-\hat{\mathbf z}}
{r^{3}}},
\qquad r>R .
\]

This shows that the external field consists of the original uniform field plus the field produced by an induced dipole moment

\[
\mathbf{p}=4\pi\varepsilon_0 R^{3}\frac{\varepsilon-1}{\varepsilon+2}\,E_0\,\hat{\mathbf z}.
\]

---

### 3. Special Cases

* If \(\varepsilon\to\infty\) (perfect conductor):  
  \(\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm int}}\to0\),   
  \(\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm ext}}\) reduces to the field around a conducting sphere.

* If \(\varepsilon=1\) (no dielectric contrast):  
  Both \(A\) and \(B\) vanish – the sphere does nothing;  
  \(\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm int}}=\mathbf{E}_{\!{\rm ext}}=E_0\,\hat{\mathbf z}\).

These formulas give the complete description of the static electric field distribution created when a uniformly polarized dielectric sphere is immersed in a uniform external electric field.

(\(\beta=v/c,\;\gamma=(1-\beta ^2)^{-1/2}\)).
The incident wave in \(S\) is

\[
\mathbf E_{\text{inc}}=\Re\!\left[E_0\,e^{ i(kz-\omega t)}\right],\qquad   
k=\frac{\omega}{c}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.   Transformation to the surface‑rest frame \(S'\)

For a plane wave the Lorentz transformation of the temporal and spatial frequencies is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\omega' &=\gamma (\omega-kv),\\[3pt]
k'      &=
          \gamma \Bigl(k-\dfrac{\omega v}{c^{2}}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}}
\tag{1}
\]

Using \(k=\omega/c\),

\[
\omega'=\gamma\omega(1-\beta),
\qquad
k'    =\gamma\dfrac{\omega}{c}(1-\beta).
\tag{2}
\]

Note that \(\displaystyle \frac{\omega'}{k'}=c\); the light speed is invariant.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.   Reflection in \(S'\)

In the rest–frame of the surface the interface is **stationary**, hence the
reflected wave keeps the same angular frequency \(\omega'\) while its
wavevector reverses sign:

\[
k'_{\,\! r}= -\,k'.
\tag{3}
\]

(The amplitude may change according to Fresnel coefficients, but the
frequency does not.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.   Back–transform to the laboratory frame \(S\)

Inverse Lorentz formulas give

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{\mathrm{refl}}&=\gamma\bigl(\omega'-vk'_{\,\! r}\bigr),\\[3pt]
k_{\mathrm{refl}}     &=\gamma\bigl(k'_{\,\! r}+ \omega'v/c^{2}\bigr).
\end{aligned}}
\tag{4}
\]

Insert (2) and (3):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{\mathrm{refl}}
&=\gamma\Bigl[\gamma\omega(1-\beta)\;
            -\,v(-\gamma\tfrac{\omega}{c})(1-\beta)\Bigr]\\[2mm]
&=\gamma^{2}\omega(1-\beta)\Bigl[1-\beta\Bigr]
   =\gamma^{2}\omega(1-\beta)^{2}.     
\end{aligned}
\]

Because \(\gamma^{2}=1/(1-\beta^{2})\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\omega_{\mathrm{refl}}
   =\omega\,\frac{(1-\beta)^{2}}{1-\beta^{2}}
   =\omega\,\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}\;}
\tag{5}
\]

or equivalently,

\[
f_{\mathrm{refl}}=f_{\text{inc}}\,
                   \frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta},
\qquad
\beta=\frac{v}{c}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

## Final Answer

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\omega_{\text{reflected}}
   =\omega_{\text{incident}}\,
     \frac{1-\dfrac{v}{c}}{1+\dfrac{v}{c}}
     }
\]

This is the familiar Doppler shift for a perfectly reflecting surface moving
away from the source; if the surface moved toward the source one would replace
\(v\to -v\).

\[
B_{\rm ax}(z)=\frac{\mu_{0}\,I\,a^{2}}{2\,(a^{2}+z^{2})^{3/2}}\qquad(\ast)
\]

* \(B_{\rm pole}=0.8~{\rm G}=8\times10^{-5}{\rm \,T}\).

Equation \((\*)\) therefore becomes

\[
B_{\rm pole}
    =\frac{\mu_{0}}{2\pi}\,\frac{\mathcal M}{R^{3}},
\tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a) Charge densities

The **bound‑volume charge density** follows from  

\[
\rho_{\rm b}= -\,\boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\! \mathbf P .
\]

In cylindrical coordinates (\(r,\varphi ,z\)) the divergence of a purely radial field \(F(r)\hat{\bf e}_r\) is  

\[
\nabla\!\cdot(F\hat{\bf e}_r)=\frac1r\frac{d}{dr}(rF).
\]

Hence  

\[
\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf P=
\frac1r\frac{d}{dr}
   \Bigl[r\left(\tfrac12P_{0}r\right)\Bigr]
=\frac1r\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(\tfrac12P_{0}r^{2}\bigr)
=P_{0},
\]

and therefore  

\[
\boxed{\rho_{\rm b}=-P_{0}}\quad\text{inside }(r<a).
\]

At the lateral surface \(r=a\) the **surface‐bound charge density** is  

\[
\sigma_{\rm b}= \mathbf P\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf n}
               =\mathbf P(a)\!\cdot\!\hat{\bf e}_r
               =\frac12P_{0}a ,
\]

so that the whole cylinder carries a uniform negative bulk charge together with a positively charged rim.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b) Magnetic field on the axis while rotating

When the cylinder spins with constant angular speed \(\boldsymbol\omega=\omega\,\hat{\bf e}_z\),
the bound charge density \(\rho_{\rm b}\) moves with the material.  
Its drift velocity at radius \(r\) is  

\[
\mathbf v=\boldsymbol\omega\times\mathbf r
          =\omega\,r\,\hat{\bf e}_{\varphi}.
\]

Consequently the **current density** associated with the moving bound charge is  

\[
\mathbf J_{\rm b}= \rho_{\rm b}\,\mathbf v
                  =(-P_{0})\,(\omega r\,\hat{\bf e}_{\varphi})
                  =-P_{0}\,\omega\,r\,\hat{\bf e}_{\varphi}.      \tag{1}
\]

Because the problem is axially symmetric and we look at points well inside the cylinder,
we may take the fields to be independent of \(z\) and \(\varphi\); hence the magnetic field can contain only a \(z\)-component, \( \mathbf B=B_z(r)\,\hat{\bf e}_z\).

From Ampère’s law,

\[
\nabla\times\mathbf B=\mu _0\,\mathbf J_{\rm b},
\]

and in cylindrical coordinates the only non‑vanishing component of the left side is  

\[
(\nabla\times\mathbf B )_\varphi
    =-\frac{\partial B_z}{\partial r}.
\]

Equating this to the \(\varphi\)-component of Eq.(1),

\[
-\frac{\partial B_z}{\partial r}
     =\mu_0\,J_{\rm b}^{(\varphi)}
     =-\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,r ,
\]

gives

\[
\frac{\partial B_z}{\partial r}
        =\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,r .
\]

Integrating from the centre (\(r=0\)) to arbitrary \(r\le a\):

\[
B_z(r)=\frac12\,\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,r^{2}+C .
\]

Regularity at the axis forces \(C=0\).  
Therefore inside the cylinder

\[
\boxed{\,B_z(r)=\frac12\,\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,r^{2}\,},\qquad (r<a).
\]

On the very axis (\(r=0\)), the field vanishes locally, but the **net axial field generated by the whole rotating cylinder**—which is what is measured at a point on the axis sufficiently far from the ends—is obtained by taking the limit \(r\to a^{-}\):

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
B_{\parallel}&\equiv B_z(r=a^-)
              =\frac12\,\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,a^{2}\\[3pt]
             &\;\;\hbox{pointing antiparallel to }\boldsymbol\omega
            \end{aligned}}
\]

(The minus sign comes from the fact that the actual current density in Eq.\,(1) runs clockwise when viewed from above, whereas the conventional “positive” circulation is counter‑clockwise.)

\boxed{\displaystyle
B_{\text{axis}}=-\frac12\,\mu_0\,P_{0}\,\omega\,a^{2}\;
\hat{\bf e}_z }

For a thin metallic spherical shell of radius \(b\) carrying a total charge \(Q\)

---

### (a)   Capacitance  

The electrostatic potential of a charged isolated sphere is  

\[
V=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,b}\qquad(\text{outside } r>b)
\]

Hence  

\[
C=\frac{Q}{V}=4\pi\varepsilon _0\,b .
\]

---

### (b)   Energy density of the electric field  

Inside the metal (\(r<b\)) the field vanishes, therefore the energy density is zero.  
Outside the sphere (\(r>b\))

\[
E(r)=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,r^{2}},\qquad 
u(r)=\frac12\,\varepsilon _0\,E^{2}
      =\frac{Q^{2}}{32\pi ^{2}\,\varepsilon _0\,r^{4}}\;\;(r>b).
\]

---

### (c)   Total electromagnetic energy stored in the field  

Only the exterior region contributes:

\[
U=\int_{\text{all space}}u\,d\tau=
    \int_{b}^{\infty}\!\left[\frac{Q^{2}}
          {32\pi ^{2}\varepsilon _0\,r^{4}}\right]
        4\pi r^{2}\,dr
     =\frac{Q^{2}}{8\pi \varepsilon _0\,b}.
\]

This can also be written as  

\[
U=\frac12CV^{2}=\frac{Q^{2}}{2C},
\quad C=4\pi\varepsilon _0 b,
\]

which gives the same value.

---

### (d)   Work required to bring the charge from infinity  

When an element \(dq\) is brought from infinity to the already‑charged sphere, it experiences the instantaneous potential \(V(q)=q/(4\pi\varepsilon _0 b)\):

\[
W=\int_{0}^{Q}V(q)\,dq
  =\int_{0}^{Q}\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon _0 b}\,dq
  =\frac{Q^{2}}{8\pi \varepsilon _0\,b}.
\]

Again identical to the previous results.

### (e)   Radius of the inner sphere giving a **minimum** electric field at its surface  

Consider two concentric thin metallic spheres:
inner radius \(a\,(<b)\) and outer radius \(b\).  
They form a spherical capacitor whose capacitance is

\[
C=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,ab}{\,b-a\,}.
\]

With a voltage \(V\) applied across them, the charge on either sphere is  

\[
Q=C\,V=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,ab\,V}{\,b-a\,}.
\]

Just outside the inner sphere the radial field is

\[
E_{\rm in}(a)=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,a^{2}}
             =\frac{b\,V}{a\,(b-a)} .
\]

To minimise this field with respect to the choice of \(a\),

\[
\frac{dE_{\rm in}}{da}=0
\Longrightarrow
-\frac{bV\,(b-2a)}{\bigl[a(b-a)\bigr]^2}=0
\Longrightarrow
a=\frac{b}{2}.
\]

Because the square of the denominator is always positive, the critical point corresponds to a true minimum. Hence the electric field immediately outside the inner sphere attains its lowest possible value when the inner sphere’s radius is exactly half that of the outer sphere.

\[

\begin{aligned}
&\text{Capacitance:}& C &= 4\pi\varepsilon _0\,b\\[3pt]
&\text{Field energy density:}&
u(r)&=
\begin{cases}
0,& r<b\\[2pt]
\dfrac{Q^{2}}{32\pi ^{2}\varepsilon _0\,r^{4}},

\end{cases}\\[6pt]
&\text{Total field energy:}&
U &= \dfrac{Q^{2}}{8\pi \varepsilon _0\,b}\\[6pt]
&\text{Charging work:}&
W &= \dfrac{Q^{2}}{8\pi \varepsilon _0\,b}\\[6pt]
&\text{Optimal inner radius:}&
a &= \dfrac{b}{2}
\end{aligned}}
\]

### Charge that crosses a fixed point

Define the total charge that has passed a particular point on the loop,

\[
q=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty}i(t)\,dt ,

\]

Because \(i(t)\to0\) before the field is applied and also long after the field has reached its final value,

\[

\[
Rq = \pi a^{2}B

\]

This result holds irrespective of whether the magnetic field is turned on suddenly or smoothly—the total charge transferred depends only on the final flux and the resistance of the loop.

Let the slab occupy \(z<0\) and let the incoming wave come from the region \(z>0\).
The optical axis of the crystal coincides with the coordinate axes, therefore the
permittivity tensor is diagonal,

\[
\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}
   =\begin{pmatrix}
      n_x ^2\,\varepsilon _0 & 0&0\\ 
      0& n_y ^2\,\varepsilon _0 &0\\ 
      0&0& n_z ^2\,\varepsilon _0  
     \end{pmatrix},
    \qquad n_x\ne n_y .
\]

Because the wave impinges **normally**, the two transverse Cartesian components,
\(E_x\) and \(E_y\), do not couple – they propagate independently with the
refractive indices \(n_x,\;n_y\).  
All Fresnel coefficients that appear below are those for normal incidence.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a)  Polarisation of the reflected wave for an infinitely thick slab  

At the first interface (\(\text{air}/\text{crystal}\))

\[
r_{\!i}=\frac{1-n_i}{1+n_i},\qquad   
t_{\!i}=\frac{2}{1+n_i}\qquad (i=x,y),
\]
and there is no transmission beyond the slab.  
Consequently the reflected field contains the two independent components

\[
E_{rx}(z,t)=r_x\,E_{ix}\,e^{-ik_0(z+t)},\qquad    
E_{ry}(z,t)=r_y\,E_{iy}\,e^{-ik_0(z+t)},
\]
with \(k_0=\omega/c\).

If the incident field is linearly polarised at \(45^\circ\),

\[
E_{ix}=E_{iy}=E_0/\sqrt{2}.
\]

After reflection the amplitudes become

\[
|E_{rx}|=|r_x|\;\frac{|E_0|}{\sqrt{2}},
\qquad
|E_{ry}|=|r_y|\;\frac{|E_0|}{\sqrt{2}},
\]

while the phases remain identical (the reflection coefficient is purely real;
its sign merely changes the phase by \(0\) or \(\pi\)).  
Since \(|r_x|\neq |r_y|\;(n_x\neq n_y)\), the two orthogonal components now have
different magnitudes while keeping the same phase.  
This produces an **elliptical** polarisation whose principal axes lie along
the \(x\)‑ and \(y\)‑directions.  
In particular

\[
\tan\!\theta_\mathrm{maj}=
\left|
\frac{E_{rx}}{E_{ry}}
\right|=
\Bigl|\frac{r_x}{r_y}\Bigr|,
\qquad
\Delta\phi=0~({\rm mod }\;\pi ),
\]

so the ellipse is aligned with the crystallographic axes and its eccentricity
is set by the ratio \(|r_x/r_y|\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)  Transmitted field through a slab of thickness \(d\)

Inside the crystal the wavenumbers are

\[
k_i=n_i\,k_0=\frac{n_i\omega }{c}\qquad (i=x,y),
\]
hence the round‑trip phase accumulated over one pass across the slab is

\[
\delta_i=k_id=\frac{n_i\omega d}{c}.
\]

Using the standard Fabry–Pérot result for a single resonant cavity bounded by
two parallel plates, the complex transmission coefficient for each
Cartesian component reads

\[
T_i=\frac{t_{01}^{(i)}\,t_{10}^{(i)}
          \exp(i\delta_i)}
         {1+r_{01}^{(i)}\,r_{10}^{(i)}\exp(2i\delta_i)} ,
        \qquad i=x,y .
\tag{1}
\]

With the normal‑incidence Fresnel numbers introduced earlier,

\[
r_{01}^{(i)}=r_i=\frac{1-n_i}{1+n_i},\qquad
t_{01}^{(i)}=\frac{2}{1+n_i},
\]
\[
r_{10}^{(i)}=-\,r_i,\qquad
t_{10}^{(i)}=\frac{2n_i}{1+n_i},
\]

eq.(1) simplifies to

\[
\boxed{
T_i=
\frac{4\,n_i}{(1+n_i)^2}\;
\frac{\displaystyle e^{\,i\delta_i}}
       {\displaystyle 1+r_i^{\,2}\,e^{\,2i\delta_i}}\!,
\qquad
r_i=\frac{1-n_i}{1+n_i}\!.
}
\tag{2}
\]

The transmitted electric field is therefore

\[
\mathbf{E}_t(z,t)=
\bigl[T_x\,E_{ix}\,\hat{x}+T_y\,E_{iy}\,\hat{y}\bigr]\,
e^{\,i(k_0z-\omega t)} .
\]

\[

   =\frac{n_x}{n_y}\;

                      {1-r_y^{\,2}\cos(2\delta_y)} .

These give respectively the **relative magnitude** and the **phase offset**

   =\frac{i\,e^{2}n}{m\omega}\,\tilde{{\bf E}}\,

\]

\[
\boxed{{\bf J}= i\sigma_{\!0}\,{\bf E},
      \quad
      \sigma_{\!0}\equiv\frac{e^{2}n}{m\omega}}
\tag{1}

\nabla\times{\bf E}=-\mu _0\frac{\partial{\bf H}}{\partial t},
\qquad

        \frac{\partial{\bf E}}{\partial t}.
\]

\tag{2}
\]

\[
\nabla\times(\nabla\times{\bf E})
    =-\mu _0\frac{\partial}{\partial t}

\]

\[

   =-\mu _0\Bigl[-i\omega(i\omega\varepsilon _0+i\sigma_{\!0})\Bigr]{\bf E}

For a non‑relativistic charged particle moving on a circular Keplerian orbit the only source of energy loss is the dipole radiation emitted while the charge accelerates around the centre.  
Using the Larmor formula one obtains a simple ordinary differential equation for the instantaneous radius \(R(t)\).

---

### 1.   Basic relations  

*Coulomb force*

\[
F_{\rm C}= \frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{R^{2}},\qquad 
k_{\!e}\equiv\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon _0}.
\]

With a fixed central charge this provides the required centripetal force,

\[
m\,v^{2}/R = F_{\rm C}
      \;\Longrightarrow\;
v^{2}= \frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{mR},
\]
and hence the orbital angular velocity

\[
\omega ^2=\frac{v^{2}}{R^{2}}
          =\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{mR^{3}} .
\]

Acceleration magnitude

\[
a=\frac{v^{2}}{R}= \frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{mR^{2}} .
\]

Total mechanical energy of the two–body system (the heavy partner being stationary)

\[
E(R)=K+V=
     \frac12mv^{2}-\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{R}
    =-\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{2R}.            \tag{1}
\]

---

### 2.   Power radiated – Larmor formula  

In SI units the non‑relativistic Larmor power is

\[
P=\frac{q^{2}a^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon _0c^{3}},
\quad
a=\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{mR^{2}} ,
\]

hence

\[
P(R)
   =\frac{q^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon _0c^{3}}
     \left(\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{mR^{2}}\right)^{\!\!2}
   =\frac{q^{6}}{96\pi^{3}\epsilon _0^{3}m^{2}c^{3}R^{4}}.        \tag{2}
\]

---

### 3.   Radius evolution

Radiation removes mechanical energy:
\(P=-\dot E\).
From Eq.(1),

\[
\dot E=\frac{dE}{dR}\,\dot R
       =\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{2R^{2}}\dot R,
\]
so that

\[
-P=\frac{k_{\!e}q^{2}}{2R^{2}}\dot R
   \;\Longrightarrow\;
\boxed{\displaystyle
\dot R
   =-\frac{2R^{2}}{k_{\!e}q^{2}}\,P }           \tag{3}
\]

Insert Eq.(2):

\[
\dot R
   =-\frac{2R^{2}}{k_{\!e}q^{2}}
     \cdot\frac{q^{6}}{96\pi^{3}\epsilon _0^{3}m^{2}c^{3}R^{4}}
   =-
     \frac{q^{4}}{12\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}\,
     \frac{1}{R^{2}}.                           \tag{4}
\]

Equation (4) separates immediately:

\[
R^{2}\,dR
   =-\Bigl[\frac{q^{4}}{12\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}\Bigr]\,
     dt .
\]

Integrating from the initial radius \(R_{i}=R\) at \(t=0\) to the desired radius
\(R_{f}=R/2\) at time \(t=T\),

\[
\int_R^{R/2}R'^2\,dR'
   =-\frac{q^{4}}{12\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}\,
     \int_0^{T}dt .
\]

The left hand side evaluates to

\[
\biggl.\frac{R'^3}{3}\biggr|_{R}^{R/2}
   =\frac{1}{3}\!\left[(R/2)^3-R^3\right]
   =-\frac{7R^{3}}{24}.
\]

Equating both sides gives

\[
-\frac{7R^{3}}{24}
   =-\frac{q^{4}}{12\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}\,T
   \;\Longrightarrow\;
T
   =\frac{7}{2}\,
     \frac{\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}{q^{4}}\,
     R^{3}.                                      \tag{5}
\]

---

### 4.   Alternative compact form

Introduce the fine–structure constant
\(
\alpha=\dfrac{q^{2}}{4\pi\epsilon _0\hbar c}
\),
then \(q^{4}=16\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}\hbar ^{2}c^{2}\alpha ^{2}\).
Replacing this in Eq.(5) simplifies the prefactor:

\[
T
   =\frac{7m^{2}c}{32\hbar ^{2}\alpha ^{2}}\,
     R^{3}.                                       \tag{6}
\]

Both expressions give exactly the same numerical value.

---

## Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
T
   =\frac{7}{2}\,
     \frac{\pi^{2}\epsilon _0^{2}m^{2}c^{3}}{q^{4}}\,
     R^{3}
   \;=\;
   \frac{7m^{2}c}{32\hbar ^{2}\alpha ^{2}}\,
     R^{3}
}
\]

where \(m\) is the light particle’s mass, \(q\) its charge, \(R\) the initial orbital radius, \(c\) the speed of light, \(\epsilon _0\) the vacuum permittivity, \(\hbar\) Planck’s reduced constant, and \(\alpha\simeq 1/137\) the fine‑structure constant. This is the time taken for the orbit to contract from radius \(R\) down to \(R/2\) owing solely to classical electromagnetic radiation losses.

\tag{1}

while in medium 2 the potential is that of a single charge

\[
q_T\;=\;\frac{2\varepsilon _1}{\varepsilon _1+\varepsilon _2}\;q ,
\quad
\hbox{situated at }(0,0,d).
\tag{2}
\]

These expressions follow from imposing the boundary conditions

\[
\begin{cases}
\phi_1=\phi_2 &\text{at }z=0 ,\\[3pt]
\varepsilon _1\,E_{1n}= \varepsilon _2\,E_{2n}&\text{at }z=0 .

Because the two real charges sit in different media, each produces an image

| Medium | Real charge | Image charge |
|--------|-------------|--------------|
| \(z>0\) | \(-q\) at \((0,0,a)\) | \((-q')\) at \((0,0,-a)\) – image of \(-q\) |
|        |             | \(+(q_T)\) at \((0,0,a)\) – image of \(+q\) |

Only the *non‑self* parts of these fields act on the negative charge.

* the real positive charge \(+q\) at \((0,0,-a)\);
* the image of the positive charge in medium 1, namely \(+q_T\) at \((0,0,a)\);

\[

\]

= q\!\left(

Thus finally

\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\varepsilon _1}\;
\frac{q}{(2a)^{2}}\;\hat{\bf z}

The negative charge experiences an electrostatic force

### (a) Total induced charge on the sheet  

Because the plane is kept at zero electric potential, the integral of the surface‑charge density over the whole plane must cancel the external source charge:
\[
Q_{\rm ind}= -\,q .
\]
Hence,
\[
\boxed{Q_{\rm ind}= -\,2~{\mu}\mathrm{C}} .
\]

---

### (b) Force on the real charge  

Only the image charge exerts a force on the real charge.  
With Coulomb’s law,
\[
F=\frac{k\,q_1q_2}{d^{\,2}}
   =\frac{k(+q)(-q)}{(2a)^2}
   =-\frac{k\,q^{2}}{4a^{2}},
\]
the minus sign indicating attraction toward the plane.  
Using \(k=8.99\times10^{9}\,\mathrm{N\,m^{2}/C^{2}}\),
\(q=2\times10^{-6}\,\mathrm{C}\) and \(a=0.10\,\mathrm{m}\),

\[
|F|
    =\frac{8.99\times10^{9}(2\times10^{-6})^{2}}{4(0.10)^{2}}
    \approx 0.90~\mathrm{N}.
\]

So the force points perpendicular to the plane, pulling the charge toward it:

\[
\boxed{|F|\simeq 0.90~\mathrm{N}\;\text{toward the plane}.}
\]

---

### (c) Work required to pull the charge out to infinity  

The electrostatic potential energy of the pair \((+q,-q)\) when they are separated by \(2a\) is

\[
U(a)=\frac{k\,q_{1}q_{2}}{2a}
     =-\frac{k\,q^{2}}{2a},
\qquad 
U(\infty)=0 .
\]

Therefore the work that must be supplied to bring the charge from its initial position (\(a\)) to infinity is

\[
W = -\bigl(U(a)-U(\infty)\bigr)
   =+\frac{k\,q^{2}}{2a}.
\]

\[

\frac{8.99\times10^{9}\,(2\times10^{-6})^{2}}{2(0.10)}
\simeq 0.18~\mathrm{J}.
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{W \approx 0.18~\mathrm{J}} .
\]

---

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)} && Q_{\rm ind}= -2~\mu\mathrm{C},\\[2pt]
&\text{(b)} && |F|\approx 0.90~\mathrm{N}\quad(\text{attracting toward the plane}),\\[2pt]
&\text{(c)} && W\approx 0.18~\mathrm{J}.

\]

### (a) Radius of the grounded sphere  

Place the centre of the sphere at the origin \(O\).  
The two identical charges \(+Q\) sit on the \(x\)-axis at

\[
P_{+}\;(x=+d)\qquad P_{-}\;(x=-\,d),
\]

so that the distance between them is \(2d\).  
Because the sphere is **grounded**, the potential on its surface is zero.  
With the method of images each exterior charge produces an interior “image’’
charge

\[
q_{\text{im}}=-\,Q\,\frac{R}{d},
\qquad 
{\bf r}_{\text{im}}
=\pm\,\hat{x}\,\frac{R^{2}}{d}
\quad(\hbox{sign follows the real charge}),
\]

where \(R\) is the radius of the sphere (\(d>R\)).
All fields are obtained by superposing the effects of the two real charges,
their two images and the sphere itself.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### Forces acting on the charge at \(P_{+}(+d)\)

| Source | Position | Charge | Separation |\(|\mathbf{F}| \)| Direction |
|--------|----------|-------|------------|-----------------|-----------|
| other real charge \(+Q\) | \((-d,0,0)\) | \(+Q\) | \(2d\) | \(\displaystyle k\frac{Q^{2}}{(2d)^{2}}\) | to the right (+) |
| its own image \(-q_{\rm im}\) | \((+\tfrac{R^{2}}{d},0,0)\) | \(-q_{\rm im}=+Q\dfrac{R}{d}\) | \(d-\tfrac{R^{2}}{d}=\dfrac{d^{2}-R^{2}}{d}\) | \(\displaystyle k\frac{Q^{2}Rd}{(d^{2}-R^{2})^{2}}\) | to the left (–) |
| image of the other charge \(-q_{\rm im}'\) | \((-\tfrac{R^{2}}{d},0,0)\) | \(-q_{\rm im}'=+Q\dfrac{R}{d}\) | \(d+\tfrac{R^{2}}{d}=\dfrac{d^{2}+R^{2}}{d}\) | \(\displaystyle k\frac{Q^{2}Rd}{(d^{2}+R^{2})^{2}}\) | to the left (–) |

(The symbol \(k=1/(4\pi\varepsilon _0)\).)

Setting the resultant force to zero,

\[
k\frac{Q^{2}}{4d^{2}}
-
k\frac{Q^{2}Rd}{(d^{2}-R^{2})^{2}}
-
k\frac{Q^{2}Rd}{(d^{2}+R^{2})^{2}}
=0 .
\]

After cancelling common factors and introducing the dimensionless quantity
\(x=R/d(<1)\),

\[
\boxed{
\;\;
x\Bigl[\frac{1}{(1-x^{2})^{2}}+
      \frac{1}{(1+x^{2})^{2}}\Bigr]=\frac14
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

which reduces to the eighth‑degree polynomial

\[
x^{8}-8x^{5}-2x^{4}-8x+1=0 .
\]

Its physical root is

\[
x\simeq 0.1249\approx\frac18 ,
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
\boxed{\,R\;\simeq\;\frac{d}{8}\, } .
\]

Numerical evaluation confirms that this choice makes the net force on either
real charge vanish.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Force when the sphere carries a potential \(V\)

When the sphere is **not grounded** but maintained at a prescribed
potential \(V\), the image construction is modified by adding a
central charge \(Q_{C}\) whose value guarantees the required potential.
For a spherical conductor of radius \(R\),

\[
V=\frac{k\,Q_{C}}{R}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
Q_{C}= \frac{VR}{k}.
\]

The rest of the image system – the two ordinary image charges –
remains unchanged.  
Consequently the force on the charge at \(P_{+}\) receives an additional
contribution from the central charge:

\[
|\mathbf{F}_C|=
k\,\frac{QQ_C}{d^{2}}
=
k\,\frac{QV\,R}{kd^{2}}
=
\frac{QV\,R}{d^{2}},
\qquad\text{directed toward the centre}. 
\]

Because the remaining three forces were arranged to cancel in part (a),
the total force is solely this new term:

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf{F}_{(+)} =
-\frac{QV\,R}{d^{2}}\;\hat{\mathbf{x}}
\;} .
\]

Substituting the radius found in part (a):

\[
R=\frac{d}{8}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\boxed{\;
|\mathbf{F}_{(+)}|=\frac{QV}{8d}
\;}
\]

and the force acts toward the centre of the sphere (i.e., opposite to
the mutual electrostatic repulsion of the two real charges).

Both charges feel the same magnitude of force, pointing inward.

For a classical Coulombic two–body system the instantaneous mechanical energy of a circular orbit of radius \(r\) is  

\[
E(r)\;=\;-\,\frac{k_e e^{2}}{2r},\qquad 
k_e=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon _0},
\]
and its angular velocity follows from Newton’s second law  
\(m v^{2}/r=k_e e^{2}/r^{2}\):

\[
\omega ^2=\frac{k_e e^{2}}{mr^{3}},\qquad   
v=r\omega .
\]

---

### Power radiated

In the non‑relativistic limit the Larmor formula gives the radiated power

\[
P=\frac{e^{2}a^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon _0c^{3}},
\quad a=v^{2}/r=\omega ^{2}r ,
\]

so that

\[
P=\frac{e^{2}\,\omega ^{4}r^{2}}
      {6\pi\varepsilon _0c^{3}}
   =\frac{e^{2}(k_e e^{2})^{2}}
          {6\pi\varepsilon _0c^{3}m^{2}r^{4}} .
\tag{1}
\]

(The last equality uses \(\omega ^4=(k_e e^{2})^{2}/(m^{2}r^{6})\).)

---

### Orbital shrinkage rate

Because the emitted power reduces the bound‐state energy,

\[
\frac{\mathrm dE}{\mathrm dt}= -P .
\]

With \(E(r)=-k_e e^{2}/(2r)\),

\[
\frac{\mathrm dE}{\mathrm dr}
     =+\frac{k_e e^{2}}{2r^{2}},
\qquad
\Rightarrow\;
\frac{\mathrm dE}{\mathrm dt}
    =\frac{k_e e^{2}}{2r^{2}}\,
       \dot r .
\]

Equating this to \(-P\) and inserting Eq.(1) gives

\[
\frac{k_e e^{2}}{2r^{2}}\;\dot r
        =-\frac{e^{2}(k_e e^{2})^{2}}
                {6\pi\varepsilon _0c^{3}m^{2}r^{4}},
\]

which after simplification becomes

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\dot r=
-\frac{k_e e^{2}}{3\pi\varepsilon _0c^{3}m^{2}}\,
\frac{1}{r^{2}}
 }                                           
\tag{2}
\]

or, writing explicitly \(k_e=1/(4\pi\varepsilon _0)\),

\[
\dot r=
-\frac{e^{2}}{12\pi^{2}\varepsilon _0^{2}c^{3}m^{2}}\,
\frac{1}{r^{2}} .
\]

---

### Collapse time

Equation (2) separates variables:

\[
dt=-\Bigl[\frac{12\pi^{2}\varepsilon _0^{2}c^{3}m^{2}}
               {e^{2}}\Bigr]\,r^{2}\,dr .
\]

Integrating from the initial Bohr radius \(a_{B}\) down to \(r=0\),

\[
T=\int_{0}^{a_{B}}
   \!\left[-\frac{12\pi^{2}\varepsilon _0^{2}c^{3}m^{2}}
                 {e^{2}}\right]\!
   r^{2}\,dr
   =\frac{4\pi^{2}\varepsilon _0^{2}c^{3}m^{2}}{e^{2}}\,
     a_{B}^{3}.
\]

Using the quantum definition of the Bohr radius  

\[
a_{B}=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon _0\hbar ^{2}}{m e^{2}},
\]

the result may be written entirely in fundamental constants:

\[
\boxed{
T
=\frac{256\,\pi^{5}\,\varepsilon _0^{5}\,c^{3}\,\hbar ^{6}}
         {m\,e^{8}}
 }
\]

Numerically this evaluates to about \(10^{32}\ {\rm yr}\); thus a purely classical hydrogen atom would take far longer than the age of the Universe to spiral into the nucleus under electromagnetic radiation alone.

### (a)   Relation among \(v,\;n\) and the Cherenkov angle  

Let a charge move along the \(z\)-axis with speed  
\(v=\beta\,c\;(0<\beta<1)\).
At time \(t\) it emits a spherical EM‑wavefront whose radius grows as  
\(ct_{\text{em}}\).  
Because the medium slows down the waves, after a later instant \(T\)
the point of emission lies behind the sphere’s surface.  
The envelope of all these spheres is a hollow cone whose half‑angle
is \(\theta\).

Geometrically,

\[
\cos\theta=\frac{\text{distance travelled by the particle}}
                 {\text{radius of the wavefront}}=
          \frac{vT}{cT}
        =\frac{v}{c}\;\frac{1}{n}
        =\frac{1}{\beta n}.
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
      \cos\theta=\frac{1}{\beta\,n}},\qquad
      (\beta>\tfrac{1}{n}) .
\]

This is the fundamental Cherenkov condition.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Threshold kinetic energy of an electron in H₂ gas  

Threshold occurs when \(\beta_{\rm th}=1/n\):

\[
n=1+\Delta ,\quad \Delta=1.35\times10^{-4},
\]
so

\[
\beta_{\rm th}=\frac{1}{1+\Delta}\simeq 1-\Delta ,
\qquad
1-\beta_{\rm th}^{2}\simeq 2\Delta .
\]

Relativistic Lorentz factor

\[
\gamma_{\rm th}
    =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{\rm th}^{2}}}
    \simeq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\Delta}}
    =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2.70\times10^{-4}}}
    \approx 60.8 .
\]

With the electron rest mass  
\(m_{e}c^{2}=0.511\;{\rm MeV}\),

\[
K_{\min }=(\gamma_{\rm th}-1)m_{e}c^{2}
         \approx (60.8-1)\,(0.511)\;
           \mathrm{MeV}
         \approx 3.1\times10^{1}\;{\rm MeV}.
\]

\[
\boxed{K_{\min }\;\approx\;3.1\times10^{1}\ {\rm MeV}\;( \sim 30\;{\rm MeV}).}
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Error on the inferred rest mass

From part (a)

\[
\cos\theta=\frac{1}{\beta n},\qquad
\Rightarrow\;-\,\sin\theta\,d\theta=-\frac{1}{\beta ^{2}n}\,d\beta,
\]
hence

\[
d\theta=\frac{d\beta}{\beta ^{2}n\,\tan\theta}\; .
\tag{1}
\]

For a particle of fixed laboratory momentum \(p\),
its speed is

\[
\beta=\frac{p}{\sqrt{p^{2}+m_{0}^{2}}},
\]

and therefore

\[
\frac{d\beta}{dm_{0}}
     =-\frac{pm_{0}}{(p^{2}+m_{0}^{2})^{3/2}}
     \;\xrightarrow[p\gg m_{0}]{}\;
       -\,\frac{m_{0}}{p^{2}}\; .
\tag{2}
\]

In the experiment  
\(p=100\;{\rm GeV}/c,\; m_{0}\!\approx\!1\;{\rm GeV}/c^{2}\);
thus \(p\gg m_{0}\) and Eq.(2) applies.

Using \(n\simeq1\) and \(\beta\simeq1\) in (1) and inserting (2),

\[
d\theta\simeq
\frac{m_{0}}{p^{2}}\,
\frac{dm_{0}}{\tan\theta}
            \;\Longrightarrow\;
\frac{dm_{0}}{m_{0}}
      \simeq
      \left(\frac{p^{2}}{m_{0}^{2}}\right)
      \tan\theta\,d\theta .
\]

Since the Cherenkov angle itself is tiny,

\[
\theta\simeq\sqrt{2(1-\cos\theta)}
          \simeq\sqrt{2\bigl(n\beta-1\bigr)}\!,
\]
with \(n\beta\simeq1.000135\); hence

\[
\theta\simeq\sqrt{2\times1.35\times10^{-4}}
          \approx 1.64\times10^{-2}\ {\rm rad}.
\]

Finally, substituting numerical values

\[
\frac{\delta m_{0}}{m_{0}}
   \simeq
   \Bigl(\frac{p^{2}}{m_{0}^{2}}\Bigr)
   \theta\,\delta\theta
   =
   (100)^{2}\,(1.64\times10^{-2})(1\times10^{-3})
   \approx 1.6\times10^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{\delta m_{0}}{m_{0}}\;\approx\;0.16\;\;({\rm about}\;16\%) }
\]

(The result is obtained to first order in the small parameters
\(\Delta,n-1,\theta,\delta\theta\).)

### 1.   Fields created by the beam  

For an infinitely long, cylindrically symmetric beam of electrons

\[
\rho =-ne .
\]

*Volume–current density* :    
\[
{\bf J}= \rho\,{\bf v}= -ne\,v\,{\hat {\bf z}}
      \qquad ({\rm C/m}^{3})
\]
(the minus sign reflects that the electrons themselves carry negative
charge).

Because the beam is axially symmetric, only the radial component of the
electrostatic field exists:
\[
E_r(r)=\frac{\rho\,r}{2\varepsilon _0}
       =-\frac{ne\,r}{2\varepsilon _0},
        \qquad (r<a)
\tag{1}
\]

The magnetic field follows from Ampère’s law,
using the current carried by the electrons (the “conventional” current
is opposite to the electron drift):

\[
B_\phi(r)=\frac{\mu _0 I_{\rm enc}}{2\pi r},\qquad 
I_{\rm enc}= \int_0 ^r J_z\,2\pi s ds=
            -ne\,v\,\pi r^{2}.
\]

Hence

\[
B_\phi(r)= -\,\frac{\mu _0 ne\,v\,r}{2}.          \tag{2}
\]

(The minus sign shows that the magnetic field circulates in the
direction opposite to that produced by a positive current.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.   Lorentz force on a single electron

An electron of charge \(q=-e\) feels

\[
{\bf F}=q\bigl({\bf E}+{\bf v}\times{\bf B}\bigr).
\]

Only the radial part survives:

\[
F_r=q\Bigl(E_r+v\,B_\phi\Bigr).\tag{3}
\]

Insert (1) and (2):

\[
\begin{aligned}
F_r &=
-e\!\left(
     -\frac{ne\,r}{2\varepsilon _0}
    +v\!\left[-\,\frac{\mu _0 ne\,v\,r}{2}\right]\!
   \right)\\[4pt]
&= \frac{e^{2}nr}{2\varepsilon _0}
   \;\Bigl(1-\mu _0\varepsilon _0\,v^{2}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(\mu _0\varepsilon _0=1/c^{2}\),

\[
F_r=\frac{e^{2}nr}{2\varepsilon _0}\;
     \Bigl(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\Bigr)
   =\frac{e^{2}nr}{2\varepsilon _0\,\gamma ^{2}},
   \qquad
   \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}/c^{2}}}.
\tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.   Result

The net radial force acting on any electron in the beam is therefore

\[
\boxed{
F_{\text{net}}(r)=
\frac{e^{2}\,n}{2\varepsilon _0\,\gamma ^{2}}\; r ,
\quad\hbox{directed outward.}
}
\]

and is diminished by a factor \(1/\gamma^{2}\) for highly relativistic

\[

   =\tau\,z .
\]

Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(z)&=
\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon _0}\!
      \iint_{\mathbb {R} ^2}
        \frac{\tau\,z }
             {( (x-x')^2 +(y-y')^2+z^2 )^{3/2}}

\end{aligned}
\]

ds\,d\theta\):
\[

           \frac{s\,ds}{(s^2+z^2)^{3/2}}

       \Bigl[\frac{1}{|z|}\Bigr]\,|z|
     =\frac{\tau }{2\epsilon _0}\operatorname{sgn}(z),
\]
so that

\[
\boxed{
\Phi(z)=
\begin{cases}
+\displaystyle\frac{\tau}{2\epsilon _0}, & z>0\\[6pt]
-\displaystyle\frac{\tau}{2\epsilon _0},& z<0
\end{cases}}
\qquad (\text{for }z\ne0).
\]

Consequently the **potential itself is discontinuous** across the sheet,

\[
\Delta\Phi\equiv \Phi(0^+)-
                 \Phi(0^-)=\frac{\tau}{\epsilon _0}.
\tag{1}
\]

Away from the sheet the field vanishes,
\( \mathbf E=-\nabla\Phi=0\);
the normal derivative therefore has no ordinary jump – the
discontinuity appears only through a Dirac–delta contribution
at the sheet.  
In short:

* \(\Phi\) is discontinuous by \(\tau/\epsilon_0\).*  
* Its spatial derivatives remain continuous (they are identically zero
outside the sheet).*

### (b) Sphere of radius \(a\) carrying a centre charge \(q\)

Inside the sphere we wish the potential to be that of the isolated
point charge,
\[
\Phi_{\rm in}(r)=\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q}{r},
\qquad 0<r<a ,
\]
while outside the sphere the potential must vanish,
\(\Phi_{\rm out}(r)=0,\; r>a.\)

Both a uniform surface‐charge density \(\sigma\) and a uniform dipole

For a thin spherical shell of radius \(a\) with surface charge

\[

No dependence on \(r\) occurs; the field generated by a perfectly

\tag{5}

The grounded conducting plane \(z=0\) is replaced by suitable image charges.  
For a point charge \(Q\) situated at \(\mathbf r _0 =(x_0 ,y_0 ,z_0)\;(z_0>0)\) the image is  

\[
-Q\quad{\rm at}\qquad \mathbf r_{\text {im}}=(x_0 ,\,y_0 ,\,-z_0),
\]

so that the potential vanishes on the plane.  
With the two real charges

\[

-q:\;\mathbf r_{-}=(-a,0,a)
\]

the corresponding images are

\[
-q:\;\mathbf r_{+}^{\,\prime}= (a,0,-a),\qquad   
+q:\;\mathbf r_{-}^{\,\prime}=(-a,0,-a).
\]

### (a)   Total force on the charge \(+q\)

The force on the real charge \(+q\) comes from the three other charges listed
above.  
Using

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf F_{ij}
=k\,\frac{q_i q_j}{|\mathbf r_i-\mathbf r_j|^{3}}
      (\,\mathbf r_i-\mathbf r_j)}
\]
(with \(k=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\))

we obtain

| source | \(\Delta\mathbf r\) | \(|\Delta\mathbf r|\) | \(\mathbf F\) |
|--------|---------------------|-----------------------|---------------|
| \(-q\) at \((-a,0,a)\) | \((2a,0,0)\) | \(2a\) | \(-\,\dfrac{kq^{2}}{4a^{2}}\,(1,0,0)\) |
| \(-q\) at \((a,0,-a)\) | \((0,0,2a)\) | \(2a\) | \(-\,\dfrac{kq^{2}}{4a^{2}}\,(0,0,1)\) |
| \(+q\) at \((-a,0,-a)\) | \((2a,0,2a)\) | \(2a\!\sqrt{2}\) | \(\dfrac{kq^{2}}{8\sqrt{2}\,a^{2}}\,(1,0,1)\) |

Adding the three vectors,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf F_{+}&=
-k\,\frac{q^{2}}{a^{2}}
\Bigl[\,
\biggl(\frac14-\frac{1}{8\sqrt{2}}\biggr)(1,0,0)
+\biggl(\frac14-\frac{1}{8\sqrt{2}}\biggr)(0,0,1)
\bigr]\\[4pt]
&=-\,k\,\frac{q^{2}}{a^{2}}\;
     \frac{2-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}{8}\;
        (1,0,1).
\end{aligned}
\]

Both \(x\)– and \(z\)–components are negative – the force pulls the charge
toward the centre of the square formed by the four charges.

Its magnitude is therefore

\[
\boxed{
|\mathbf F_{+}|=
k\,\frac{q^{2}}{a^{2}}\;
    \frac{2\sqrt{2}-1}{8}},
\qquad
\theta=\arctan\!\frac{|F_z|}{|F_x|}
          =45^\circ .
\]

(The force acts in the third‑quadrant direction \((-x,-z)\).)

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Work required to assemble the system

The electrostatic potential energy of the **real** charges in the presence of
the grounded plane equals the sum of the ordinary Coulomb interactions
between the real charges and between each real charge and every image
charge.  No “\(1/2\)” factor is necessary because each pair occurs only
once.

1. **Interaction between the two real charges**

\[
U_{rr}=k\,\frac{(+q)(-q)}{2a}
       =-\frac{kq^{2}}{2a}.
\]

2. **Inter­actions with the images**

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
+q\leftrightarrow -q_{\text{img}+}: & 
-\dfrac{kq^{2}}{2a},\\[4pt]
+q\leftrightarrow +q_{\text{img}-}: &
\dfrac{kq^{2}}{2a\sqrt{2}},\\[4pt]
-q\leftrightarrow -q_{\text{img}-}:&
\dfrac{kq^{2}}{2a\sqrt{2}},\\[4pt]
-q\leftrightarrow +q_{\text{img}+}:&
-\dfrac{kq^{2}}{2a},
\end{array}
\]

whose sum is

\[
U_{\text{imgs}}
=-\frac{kq^{2}}{a}
+\frac{kq^{2}}{a\sqrt{2}} .
\]

Adding everything,

\[
U_{\text{tot}}
=U_{rr}+U_{\text{imgs}}
= k\,\frac{q^{2}}{a}
   \Bigl(
   -\frac32+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
   \Bigr).
\]

This is the change in electrostatic energy when the two charges are brought
from infinity onto the specified positions while the plane remains
grounded.  
If one wishes the mechanical work supplied against the forces, it is the
negative of this quantity:

\[
\boxed{
W_{\text{supplied}}
= -U_{\text{tot}}
= k\,\frac{q^{2}}{a}
   \Bigl(
   \frac32-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
   \Bigr)
\simeq 0.793\,\frac{kq^{2}}{a}} .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Surface‐charge density at \((a,0,0)\)

On the grounded plane the potential is identically zero.  
Just outside the conductor the normal component of the electric field is

\[
E_\perp = -\frac{\partial\Phi}{\partial z}\Bigg|_{z\to 0^{+}},
\qquad
\sigma = \varepsilon_0\,E_\perp ,
\]

where \(\Phi\) is the potential created by the real charges.

At the observation point \((a,0,z)\),

\[
\Phi(z)=kq\!
\left[
\frac{1}{a-z}
-
\frac{1}{\sqrt{4a^{2}+(z-a)^{2}}}
\right].
\]

Differentiating with respect to \(z\) and setting \(z\rightarrow 0^{+}\),

\[
\frac{\partial\Phi}{\partial z}
=kq\left[
\frac{1}{a^{2}}
+
\frac{-a}{(a\sqrt{5})^{3}}
\right]
=
kq\,\frac{1}{a^{2}}
\left(
1-\frac{1}{5\sqrt{5}}
\right).
\]

Consequently

\[
\sigma(a,0,0)
=-\varepsilon_0\,\frac{\partial\Phi}{\partial z}
=-\frac{q}{4\pi a^{2}}
\left(
1-\frac{1}{5\sqrt{5}}
\right).
\]

Numerically

\[
\sigma(a,0,0)\approx
-0.91\,\frac{q}{4\pi a^{2}},
\]

which is indeed negative, reflecting the accumulation of negative induced
surface charge beneath the positively charged ion.

A grounded perfectly‑conducting plane \(z=0\) can be treated with the method of images.  
Place the physical dipole  

\[
\mathbf P=P_x\,\hat {\mathbf x}+P_y\,\hat{\mathbf y}+P_z\,\hat{\mathbf z}
\qquad (\text{at }\;\mathbf r _0 =(0,0 ,z_0))
\]

and introduce an image dipole at \(\mathbf r'_0=(0,0 ,-z_0)\) whose moment satisfies the
boundary condition \(V(x,y,0)=0\).  
Requiring the potential to vanish on the plane gives

\[
\boxed{
\mathbf P'\!=-\bigl(P_x,\;P_y,\;-P_z\bigr)}
\tag{1}
\]
(i.e. the transverse components change sign while the longitudinal component keeps its sign).

---

### Electric field just above the plane

Denote a generic point on the upper half–space by  
\( \mathbf r=(x,y,z)\;(z>0)\),
with polar radius \( \rho=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\) and azimuthal angle \(\phi\).
Distances to the real and image sources are

\[
R_\pm=\sqrt{\rho ^2+(z\mp z_0)^2},
\qquad
\mathbf R_\pm=
\rho\cos\phi\,\hat{\mathbf x}
+\rho\sin\phi\,\hat{\mathbf y}
\pm (z\mp z_0)\hat{\mathbf z}.
\]

The electrostatic potential produced by the pair is

\[
\Phi(\mathbf r)=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}
\left(
\frac{\mathbf P\!\cdot\!\mathbf R_+}{R_+^{\,3}}
+
\frac{\mathbf P'\!\cdot\!\mathbf R_-}{R_-^{\,3}}\right).
\]

Taking the derivative with respect to \(z\) and letting \(z\to0^+\),

\[
E_z(0^+)=-
\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}
\Biggl[
2\,\frac{P_z}{R^{3}}
+6\,\frac{z_0}{R^{6}}
\bigl(P_xx+P_yy-P_z z_0\bigr)
\Biggr],
\quad
R^2=\rho^2+z_0^2 .
\]

(The algebra follows from differentiating each term,
using \(\partial R_\pm/\partial z=\pm(z\mp z_0)/R_\pm\) and
evaluating at \(z=0\).)

---

### Surface‐charge density

Inside the perfect conductor the electric field vanishes;
the jump of the normal component of \({\bf D}\) across the interface gives

\[
\sigma(x,y)=\varepsilon_0\,E_z(0^+).
\]

Substituting the previous result,

\[
\boxed{
\sigma(x,y)=
-\frac{1}{2\pi}\!
\left[
\frac{P_z}{(\rho^2+z_0^2)^{3/2}}
+
\frac{3\,z_0\,[\,P_xx+P_yy-P_z z_0\,]}
      {(\rho^2+z_0^2)^{3}}
\right]},
\qquad
\rho=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}.
\]

Equivalently, writing \(x=\rho\cos\phi,\;y=\rho\sin\phi\),

\[
\sigma(\rho,\phi)=
-\frac{1}{2\pi}\!
\left[
\frac{P_z}{(\rho^2+z_0^2)^{3/2}}
+
\frac{3\,z_0\,\rho\,
       \bigl[P_{\parallel}\!\cdot\!\hat{\boldsymbol\rho}-P_z z_0\bigr]}
     {(\rho^2+z_0^2)^{3}}
\right].
\]

Here \(P_{\parallel}=(P_x,P_y,0)\) is the component of the dipole lying in the
plane, and \(\hat{\boldsymbol\rho}\) is the radial unit vector in the \(xy\)-plane.

These formulas give the complete spatial distribution of the induced surface
charge density on the grounded conducting plane caused by an arbitrarily
oriented electric dipole situated at height \(z_0\).

The three concentric shells have radii  

\[
a<b<d ,\qquad 
S_a:\;r=a,\;\;
S_b:\;r=b,\;\;
S_d:\;r=d .
\]

Inner (\(S_a\)) and outer (\(S_d\)) shells are joined by a very thin insulated wire that runs through a tiny hole in \(S_b\).
Because the wire is insulating, no charge can leave the middle shell once the system reaches equilibrium.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a)   Capacitance of the system

After the wire is attached, the inner and outer shells belong to **one single conductor** – call it “\(C_{\text{in/out}}\)” – whose potential is the same everywhere.  
All excess charge therefore resides on the outer surface of this conductor, namely on \(S_d\).

Only the middle shell \(S_b\) is a separate conductor.  
Its two surfaces are at the same radius \(r=b\); hence the electric field in the region \(b<r<d\) is produced exclusively by the net charge \(Q_B\) carried by the middle shell.

Using Gauss’ law for a spherical surface \(r\,(b<r<d)\),

\[
E(r)=\frac{Q_B}{4\pi\varepsilon _0\,r^{2}},\qquad r\ge b ,
\]
and integrating from \(r=b\) to \(r=d\) gives the potential drop between the two conductors

\[
\Delta V
    =V_{\rm mid}-V_{\rm in/out}
     =-\int_{b}^{d}\!E(r)\,{\rm d}r
     =-\frac{Q_B}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\!\left(\frac{1}{d}-\frac{1}{b}\right)
     =\frac{Q_B}{4\pi\varepsilon _0}\Bigl(\frac{1}{b}-\frac{1}{d}\Bigr).
\]

By definition \(C=\displaystyle\frac{Q_B}{\Delta V}\), whence

\[
\boxed{%
C=
\frac{4\pi\varepsilon _0}{\displaystyle\dfrac{1}{b}-\dfrac{1}{d}}
      =4\pi\varepsilon _0\,\frac{bd}{\,d-b\,}} .
\]

Notice that the capacitance is completely independent of the innermost radius \(a\).


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Distribution of a net charge \(Q_B\) on the middle shell

Denote the surface charge density on the inner and outer faces of the middle shell by  
\(\sigma_{\rm in}\;(r=b^{-})\) and \(\sigma_{\rm out}\;(r=b^{+})\),
with corresponding charges

\[
q_{\rm in}=4\pi b^{2}\sigma_{\rm in},\qquad   
q_{\rm out}=4\pi b^{2}\sigma_{\rm out},
\quad
q_{\rm in}+q_{\rm out}=Q_B .
\]

Inside the hollow region \(a<r<b\) there is no charge, so the potential there satisfies Laplace’s equation.  
With the boundary values

\[
\phi(a)=V_{\rm in/out},\qquad
\phi(b^{-})=\phi(b^{+})=\Phi,
\]

the solution is

\[
\phi(r)=V_{\rm in/out}+\frac{(b-r)}{b-a}\bigl[\Phi-V_{\rm in/out}\bigr],
\qquad a<r<b .
\]

From the jump‑condition for the displacement field at \(r=b^{-}\),

\[
\sigma_{\rm in}
   =\varepsilon_0\,\frac{{\rm d}\phi}{{\rm d}r}\Bigg|_{b^{-}}
   =\varepsilon_0\,\frac{\Phi-V_{\rm in/out}}{b-a}.
\tag{1}
\]

Outside the middle shell (\(b<r<d\)), the potential is

\[
\phi(r)=\Phi\,\frac{d}{r},\qquad b<r<d ,
\]

so that at \(r=b^{+}\)

\[
\sigma_{\rm out}
   =\varepsilon_0\,\frac{{\rm d}\phi}{{\rm d}r}\Bigg|_{b^{+}}
   =\varepsilon_0\,\frac{\Phi\,d}{b^{2}} .
\tag{2}
\]

Adding (1)–(2) and recalling that the inner and outer conductors are at the same potential,
\(V_{\rm in/out}=\Phi\), eliminates the first term in (1):
\[
\sigma_{\rm in}=0 .
\]

Consequently

\[
q_{\rm in}=0,\qquad
q_{\rm out}=Q_B .
\]

---

#### Result

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{All }Q_B\text{ resides on the OUTER surface of the middle shell;}\\
&q_{\rm in}=0,\qquad q_{\rm out}=Q_B .
\end{aligned}}
\]

This follows from the fact that the inner and outer shells, being connected, enforce a constant potential inside the cavity \(a<r<b\), thereby preventing any charge accumulation on the inner face of the middle shell.

### (a)   Laboratory frame  

The wire is at rest, the electron moves with  
\[
\mathbf v = v\,\hat {\bf x}\qquad (v\ll c)
\]
and its instantaneous transverse separation from the wire is \(y\).
An infinitesimal element of the wire produces a magnetic field

\[
\boxed{
\mathbf B=\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi y}\,\boldsymbol{\phi}}
\]

with \(\boldsymbol{\phi}\) the azimuthal unit–vector round the \(x\)-axis.  
At the point \((0,y,0)\) (\(y>0\)) the field points in the \(+\hat{\bf z}\)‑direction,
so that

\[
\mathbf B=\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi y}\;\hat{\bf z}.
\]

The Lorentz force on the electron (\(q=-e\)) is therefore

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf F_{\rm lab}&=
q\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B\\[3pt]
&=(-e)v\,\hat{\bf x}\times 
      \Bigl[\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi y}\,\hat{\bf z}\Bigr] \\[3pt]
&=e\,\frac{\mu _0 I v}{2\pi y}\;\hat{\bf y},
\end{aligned}
\]

directed **upward**, i.e. toward the wire.

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf F_{\rm lab}=+
\frac{e\,\mu_{0}Iv}{2\pi y}\;
\hat{\bf y}}\tag{1}
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Frame comoving with the electron  

Call this primed frame \(S'\).  
It moves to the left with speed \(v\) relative to the laboratory.  
All quantities are evaluated to first order in \(v/c\) but keeping the exact
Lorentz‐factor wherever necessary.

#### Transformation of the charge and current densities

In the laboratory the wire contains

* mobile electrons : charge density \(\rho_{-}= -n e\),
* immobile ions     : charge density \(\rho_{+}= +n e\),

with \(n\) the number density of each species.  
Hence the total charge density vanishes:
\(\rho_{\text{tot}}=\rho_{+}+\rho_{-}=0\).

The corresponding current density is produced solely by the drifting
electrons,

\[
\mathbf J_{\text{lab}}=n e\,v_{d}\,\hat{\bf x}=I/A\,\hat{\bf x},
\quad v_{d}=v .
\]

Under a boost of speed \(v\) along \(-\hat{\bf x}\) the charge density
transforms as

\[
\rho^{'}=\gamma\!\left(\rho-\frac{{\bf v}\cdot{\bf J}_{\text{lab}}}{c^{2}}\right)
          =-\gamma\,\frac{v\,I}{Ac^{2}},
\]
while the current density becomes

\[
{\bf J}^{'}=\gamma({\bf J}_{\text{lab}}-{\bf v}\rho )
           =\gamma\,\frac{I}{A}(1-\beta ^{2})\,\hat{\bf x}
           =\frac{I}{A}\sqrt{1-\beta ^{2}}\;\hat{\bf x},
\]
with \(\beta=v/c\) and \(\gamma=1/\sqrt{1-\beta ^{2}}\).

Because \(\rho^{'}<0\), the wire acquires a **net negative linear charge**
density

\[
\lambda^{'}=\int\rho^{'}\,dA
            =-\gamma\,\frac{v\,I}{c^{2}} .
\]

(The minus sign simply reflects the choice of convention for the
conventional current direction.)  
Its absolute value is

\[
|\lambda^{'}|
    =\gamma\,\frac{v\,I}{c^{2}}
    \approx \frac{v\,I}{c^{2}},\qquad (v\ll c).
\]

#### Electrostatic field in \(S'\)

With a uniformly distributed line charge \(|\lambda^{'}|\) the radial
electric field at distance \(y\) is

\[
E^{'}=\frac{|\lambda^{'}|}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,y}
     =\frac{v\,I}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{2}y}.
\]

Since the induced charge is negative, the field points **away** from the
wire; consequently the electron (also negative) is attracted toward the
wire.  Its force is

\[
\mathbf F^{'}
        =-e\,\mathbf E^{'}
        =\frac{e\,v\,I}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{2}y}\;\hat{\bf y}.
\]

Using \(\mu_{0}\varepsilon_{0}=1/c^{2}\) we recover exactly Eq.(1):

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf F^{'}=
\frac{e\,\mu_{0}Iv}{2\pi y}\;\hat{\bf y}}\tag{2}
\]

which is numerically identical to the laboratory result but originates
solely from an **electric** field rather than a magnetic one.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Comparison & intermediate frames  

Both expressions (1) and (2) give the **same numerical value** – the
force on the electron is invariant under Lorentz boosts.  
What differs is the physical interpretation:

| Reference frame | Field responsible | Nature of the force |
|-----------------|-------------------|---------------------|
| Laboratory      | Pure magnetic field generated by the steady current | Lorentz force \(q\mathbf v\times\mathbf B\) |
| Electron’s own  | Static electric field created by the net charge density of the wire | Coulomb force \(-e\mathbf E\) |

If we observe the system from yet another inertial frame moving to the
right with speed \(v' = v/2\), the wire possesses both a reduced
magnetic field and a finite electric field.  
To lowest order in \(v/c\) the transverse force varies smoothly between
the two limits:

\[
\mathbf F(v')
\simeq
\frac{e\,\mu_{0}I\,v}{2\pi y}\;
\bigl(1-\tfrac12\beta'^{2}\bigr)\;\hat{\bf y},
\qquad \beta'=\frac{v'}{c}.
\]

That is, the magnetic contribution diminishes as the relative speed
decreases, whereas the electric contribution grows correspondingly,
but the sum remains essentially constant (to order \(v^{2}/c^{2}\)).
Qualitatively, the force is weaker in the intermediate frame than in
either limiting case, reflecting the partial cancellation between the
two field components.
